date.text: Western Union began as a telegram company, using electricity to send messages a long distance (across the US). It was the first communications empire and set the stage for many to follow. Nowadays it's known for sending money around the world.
date.headline: Western Union Founded
Chinese Paper Money
date.text: The Tang dynasty used paper money, and it was used in China for over 500 years. It wouldn't be used in Europe for many centuries. Also, the first printing is done - using ink on a carved wooden block to transfer images.

date.headline: Common Printing Press
date.text: The common printing press was used for about 200 years.

date.headline: Johannes Gutenberg's Printing Press
date.text: In around 1450 Johanes Gutenberg used movable type to create the first modern printing press. This would have been difficult in China, where there are thousands of characters (instead of just 26 x 2). Check out this video about how the printing press works.

date.headline: Project Gutenberg Founded
date.text:
"Project Gutenberg (PG) is a volunteer effort to digitize and archive cultural works, to "encourage the creation and distribution of eBooks".[3] It was founded in 1971 by Michael S. Hart and is the oldest digital library.[4] Most of the items in its collection are the full texts of public domain books. The project tries to make these as free as possible, in long-lasting, open formats that can be used on almost any computer. As of April 2015, Project Gutenberg has over 49,200[2] items in its collection.

The releases are available in plain text but, wherever possible, other formats are included, such as HTML, PDF, EPUB, MOBI, and Plucker." Source: wikipedia.

date.headline: Papyrus used in Ancient Egypt
date.text: "Papyrus is first known to have been used in ancient Egypt (at least as far back as the First Dynasty), as the Cyperus papyrus plant was a wetland sedge that was once abundant in the Sudd of Southern Sudan along with the Nile Delta of Egypt. Papyrus was also used throughout the Mediterranean region and in Kingdom of Kush. Ancient Egyptians are thought to have used papyrus as a writing material,[2] as well as employing it commonly in the construction of other artifacts such as reed boats, mats, rope, sandals, and baskets." Source: wikipedia.

date.headline: Widespread Electric Grids in the US
From Atoms to Bits (Paper to Hard Drive)
date.text:
IBM introduced the first commercial hard drive in 1956.

"The IBM 350 Disk File, invented by Reynold Johnson, was introduced in 1956 with the IBM 305 RAMAC computer. This drive had fifty 24 inches (0.61 m) platters, with a total capacity of five million 6-bit characters (3.75 megabytes)." Source: wikipedia.

date.headline: 3D Printing Invented (and patented)
date.text: "In 1984, Chuck Hull of 3D Systems Corporation[6] developed a prototype system based on this process known as stereolithography, in which layers are added by curing photopolymers with ultraviolet light lasers." Source: Wikipedia.

date.headline: Key 3D Printing Patents Expire
date.text: Innovation in 3D printing was limited to fewer individuals because of patents applied to the technology. The key Stratasys patent expired in 2009 after 20 years. Until this time, the cheapest 3D printer you could get was more than $15,000. Now (2015) you can buy one made in Nairobi for $300-$400.

date.headline: Europeans Make Their First Paper
date.text: Thought the Chinese and Egyptians had been making paper for centuries, the Europeans didn't know how to make their own until 1309.

date.headline: Martin Luther's Theses
date.text:
(Not to be confused with Marin Luther King)

"In 1517, Martin Luther wrote to his bishop, Albert of Mainz, protesting his dislike of buying indulgences.  He added something in the letter, which would later become the famous Ninety-Five Thesis.  Luther would argue that the sale of indulgences was a violation of the original intention of confession, and that Christians were being lied to by their own church.[3]

In January 1518, Christoph von Scheurl and other friends of Luther translated the Ninety Five Theses into German, since it was originally written in Latin.  They then printed and copied it, making it one of the first documents to be done with the help of the printing press.[4]  Within two weeks, copies of the Theses had spread throughout Germany.  Within six weeks of that, the Theses had been copied across Europe.  Luther’s writings reached France, England and Italy by 1519.[5]  This greatly increased the notoriety of
Martin Luther, and it also made many other people across Europe protest the ecclesiastical structure of the Catholic Church." Source: umwblogs.org.

era.headline: Widespread Electric Grids in the US

timeline.text:
The printing press is often cited as the most important invention of all time. It allowed commoners to overthrow governments in Europe and people could read the bible on their own, in their own language, rather than listening to priests - without the printing press there wouldn't be protestants.
Other top technologies often cited include:
  • Fire
  • The Wheel
  • The Steam Engine
  • Electricity
